column2: CHAPTER 11
column3: CHAPTER eleven

column2: WE spent the remainder of the day in a condition of stupid lethargy, gazing after the retreating vessel until the darkness, hiding her from our sight, recalled us in some measure to our senses.
column3: WE spent the remainder of the day in a condition of stupid lethargy, gazing after the retreating vessel until the darkness, hiding her from our sight, recalled us in some measure to our senses.

column2: The pangs of hunger and thirst then returned, absorbing all other cares and considerations.
column3: The pangs of hunger and thirst then returned, absorbing all other cares and considerations.

column2: Nothing, however, could be done until the morning, and, securing ourselves as well as possible, we endeavoured to snatch a little repose.
column3: Nothing, however, could be done until the morning, and, securing ourselves as well as possible, we endeavoured to snatch a little repose.

column2: In this I succeeded beyond my expectations, sleeping until my companions, who had not been so fortunate, aroused me at daybreak to renew our attempts at getting up provisions from the hull.
column3: In this I succeeded beyond my expectations, sleeping until my companions, who had not been so fortunate, aroused me at daybreak to renew our attempts at getting up provisions from the hull.

column2: It was now a dead calm, with the sea as smooth as have ever known it,--the weather warm and pleasant.
column3: It was now a dead calm, with the sea as smooth as have ever known it,--the weather warm and pleasant.

column2: The brig was out of sight.
column3: The brig was out of sight.

column2: We commenced our operations by wrenching off, with some trouble, another of the forechains; and having fastened both to Peters' feet, he again made an endeavour to reach the door of the storeroom, thinking it possible that he might be able to force it open, provided he could get at it in sufficient time; and this he hoped to do, as the hulk lay much more steadily than before.
column3: We commenced our operations by wrenching off, with some trouble, another of the forechains; and having fastened both to Peters' feet, he again made an endeavour to reach the door of the storeroom, thinking it possible that he might be able to force it open, provided he could get at it in sufficient time; and this he hoped to do, as the hulk lay much more steadily than before.

column2: He succeeded very quickly in reaching the door, when, loosening one of the chains from his ankle, he made every exertion to force the passage with it, but in vain, the framework of the room being far stronger than was anticipated.
column3: He succeeded very quickly in reaching the door, when, loosening one of the chains from his ankle, he made every exertion to force the passage with it, but in vain, the framework of the room being far stronger than was anticipated.

column2: He was quite exhausted with his long stay under water, and it became absolutely necessary that some other one of us should take his place.
column3: He was quite exhausted with his long stay under water, and it became absolutely necessary that some other one of us should take his place.

column2: For this service Parker immediately volunteered; but, after making three ineffectual efforts, found that he could never even succeed in getting near the door.
column3: For this service Parker immediately volunteered; but, after making three ineffectual efforts, found that he could never even succeed in getting near the door.

column2: The condition of Augustus's wounded arm rendered it useless for him to attempt going down, as he would be unable to force the room open should he reach it, and it accordingly now devolved upon me to exert myself for our common deliverance.
column3: The condition of Augustus's wounded arm rendered it useless for him to attempt going down, as he would be unable to force the room open should he reach it, and it accordingly now devolved upon me to exert myself for our common deliverance.

column2: Peters had left one of the chains in the passage, and I found, upon plunging in, that I had not sufficient balance to keep me firmly down. I determined, therefore, to attempt no more, in my first effort, than merely to recover the other chain.
column3: Peters had left one of the chains in the passage, and I found, upon plunging in, that I had not sufficient balance to keep me firmly down. I determined, therefore, to attempt no more, in my first effort, than merely to recover the other chain.

column2: In groping along the floor of the passage for this, I felt a hard substance, which I immediately grasped, not having time to ascertain what it was, but returning and ascending instantly to the surface.
column3: In groping along the floor of the passage for this, I felt a hard substance, which I immediately grasped, not having time to ascertain what it was, but returning and ascending instantly to the surface.

column2: The prize proved to be a bottle, and our joy may be conceived when I say that it was found to be full of port wine.
column3: The prize proved to be a bottle, and our joy may be conceived when I say that it was found to be full of port wine.

column2: Giving thanks to God for this timely and cheering assistance, we immediately drew the cork with my penknife, and, each taking a moderate sup, felt the most indescribable comfort from the warmth, strength, and spirits with which it inspired us.
column3: Giving thanks to God for this timely and cheering assistance, we immediately drew the cork with my penknife, and, each taking a moderate sup, felt the most indescribable comfort from the warmth, strength, and spirits with which it inspired us.

column2: We then carefully recorked the bottle, and, by means of a handkerchief, swung it in such a manner that there was no possibility of its getting broken.
column3: We then carefully recorked the bottle, and, by means of a handkerchief, swung it in such a manner that there was no possibility of its getting broken.

column2: Having rested a while after this fortunate discovery, I again descended, and now recovered the chain, with which I instantly came up.
column3: Having rested a while after this fortunate discovery, I again descended, and now recovered the chain, with which I instantly came up.

column2: I then fastened it on and went down for the third time, when I became fully satisfied that no exertions whatever, in that situation, would enable me to force open the door of the storeroom.
column3: I then fastened it on and went down for the third time, when I became fully satisfied that no exertions whatever, in that situation, would enable me to force open the door of the storeroom.

column2: I therefore returned in despair.
column3: I therefore returned in despair.

column2: There seemed now to be no longer any room for hope, and I could perceive in the countenances of my companions that they had made up their minds to perish.
column3: There seemed now to be no longer any room for hope, and I could perceive in the countenances of my companions that they had made up their minds to perish.

column2: The wine had evidently produced in them a species of delirium, which, perhaps, I had been prevented from feeling by the immersion I had undergone since drinking it.
column3: The wine had evidently produced in them a species of delirium, which, perhaps, I had been prevented from feeling by the immersion I had undergone since drinking it.

column2: They talked incoherently, and about matters unconnected with our condition, Peters repeatedly asking me questions about Nantucket.
column3: They talked incoherently, and about matters unconnected with our condition, Peters repeatedly asking me questions about Nantucket.

column2: Augustus, too, I remember, approached me with a serious air, and requested me to lend him a pocket-comb, as his hair was full of fish-scales, and he wished to get them out before going on shore.
column3: Augustus, too, I remember, approached me with a serious air, and requested me to lend him a pocket comb, as his hair was full of fish scales, and he wished to get them out before going on shore.

column2: Parker appeared somewhat less affected, and urged me to dive at random into the cabin, and bring up any article which might come to hand.
column3: Parker appeared somewhat less affected, and urged me to dive at random into the cabin, and bring up any article which might come to hand.

column2: To this I consented, and, in the first attempt, after staying under a full minute, brought up a small leather trunk belonging to Captain Barnard.
column3: To this I consented, and, in the first attempt, after staying under a full minute, brought up a small leather trunk belonging to Captain Barnard.

column2: This was immediately opened in the faint hope that it might contain something to eat or drink.
column3: This was immediately opened in the faint hope that it might contain something to eat or drink.

column2: We found nothing, however, except a box of razors and two linen shirts.
column3: We found nothing, however, except a box of razors and two linen shirts.

column2: I now went down again, and returned without any success.
column3: I now went down again, and returned without any success.

column2: As my head came above water I heard a crash on deck, and, upon getting up, saw that my companions had ungratefully taken advantage of my absence to drink the remainder of the wine, having let the bottle fall in the endeavour to replace it before I saw them.
column3: As my head came above water I heard a crash on deck, and, upon getting up, saw that my companions had ungratefully taken advantage of my absence to drink the remainder of the wine, having let the bottle fall in the endeavour to replace it before I saw them.

column2: I remonstrated with them on the heartlessness of their conduct, when Augustus burst into tears.
column3: I remonstrated with them on the heartlessness of their conduct, when Augustus burst into tears.

column2: The other two endeavoured to laugh the matter off as a joke, but I hope never again to behold laughter of such a species: the distortion of countenance was absolutely frightful.
column3: The other two endeavoured to laugh the matter off as a joke, but I hope never again to behold laughter of such a species: the distortion of countenance was absolutely frightful.

column2: Indeed, it was apparent that the stimulus, in the empty state of their stomachs, had taken instant and violent effect, and that they were all exceedingly intoxicated.
column3: Indeed, it was apparent that the stimulus, in the empty state of their stomachs, had taken instant and violent effect, and that they were all exceedingly intoxicated.

column2: With great difficulty I prevailed upon them to lie down, when they fell very soon into a heavy slumber, accompanied with loud stertorous breathing.
column3: With great difficulty I prevailed upon them to lie down, when they fell very soon into a heavy slumber, accompanied with loud stertorous breathing.

column2: I now found myself, as it were, alone in the brig, and my reflections, to be sure, were of the most fearful and gloomy nature.
column3: I now found myself, as it were, alone in the brig, and my reflections, to be sure, were of the most fearful and gloomy nature.

column2: No prospect offered itself to my view but a lingering death by famine, or, at the best, by being overwhelmed in the first gale which should spring up, for in our present exhausted condition we could have no hope of living through another.
column3: No prospect offered itself to my view but a lingering death by famine, or, at the best, by being overwhelmed in the first gale which should spring up, for in our present exhausted condition we could have no hope of living through another.

column2: The gnawing hunger which I now experienced was nearly insupportable, and I felt myself capable of going to any lengths in order to appease it.
column3: The gnawing hunger which I now experienced was nearly insupportable, and I felt myself capable of going to any lengths in order to appease it.

column2: With my knife I cut off a small portion of the leather trunk, and endeavoured to eat it, but found it utterly impossible to swallow a single morsel, although I fancied that some little alleviation of my suffering was obtained by chewing small pieces of it and spitting them out.
column3: With my knife I cut off a small portion of the leather trunk, and endeavoured to eat it, but found it utterly impossible to swallow a single morsel, although I fancied that some little alleviation of my suffering was obtained by chewing small pieces of it and spitting them out.

column2: Toward night my companions awoke, one by one, each in an indescribable state of weakness and horror, brought on by the wine, whose fumes had now evaporated.
column3: Toward night my companions awoke, one by one, each in an indescribable state of weakness and horror, brought on by the wine, whose fumes had now evaporated.

column2: They shook as if with a violent ague, and uttered the most lamentable cries for water.
column3: They shook as if with a violent ague, and uttered the most lamentable cries for water.

column2: Their condition affected me in the most lively degree, at the same time causing me to rejoice in the fortunate train of circumstances which had prevented me from indulging in the wine, and consequently from sharing their melancholy and most distressing sensations.
column3: Their condition affected me in the most lively degree, at the same time causing me to rejoice in the fortunate train of circumstances which had prevented me from indulging in the wine, and consequently from sharing their melancholy and most distressing sensations.

column2: Their conduct, however, gave me great uneasiness and alarm; for it was evident that, unless some favourable change took place, they could afford me no assistance in providing for our common safety.
column3: Their conduct, however, gave me great uneasiness and alarm; for it was evident that, unless some favourable change took place, they could afford me no assistance in providing for our common safety.

column2: I had not yet abandoned all idea being able to get up something from below; but the attempt could not possibly be resumed until some one of them was sufficiently master of himself to aid me by holding the end of the rope while I went down.
column3: I had not yet abandoned all idea being able to get up something from below; but the attempt could not possibly be resumed until some one of them was sufficiently master of himself to aid me by holding the end of the rope while I went down.

column2: Parker appeared to be somewhat more in possession of his senses than the others, and I endeavoured, by every means in my power, to rouse him.
column3: Parker appeared to be somewhat more in possession of his senses than the others, and I endeavoured, by every means in my power, to rouse him.

column2: Thinking that a plunge in the sea-water might have a beneficial effect, I contrived to fasten the end of a rope around his body, and then, leading him to the companion-way (he remaining quite passive all the while), pushed him in, and immediately drew him out.
column3: Thinking that a plunge in the sea water might have a beneficial effect, I contrived to fasten the end of a rope around his body, and then, leading him to the companion way (he remaining quite passive all the while), pushed him in, and immediately drew him out.

column2: I had good reason to congratulate myself upon having made this experiment; for he appeared much revived and invigorated, and, upon getting out, asked me, in a rational manner, why I had so served him.
column3: I had good reason to congratulate myself upon having made this experiment; for he appeared much revived and invigorated, and, upon getting out, asked me, in a rational manner, why I had so served him.

column2: Having explained my object, he expressed himself indebted to me, and said that he felt greatly better from the immersion, afterward conversing sensibly upon our situation.
column3: Having explained my object, he expressed himself indebted to me, and said that he felt greatly better from the immersion, afterward conversing sensibly upon our situation.

column2: We then resolved to treat Augustus and Peters in the same way, which we immediately did, when they both experienced much benefit from the shock.
column3: We then resolved to treat Augustus and Peters in the same way, which we immediately did, when they both experienced much benefit from the shock.

column2: This idea of sudden immersion had been suggested to me by reading in some medical work the good effect of the shower-bath in a case where the patient was suffering from _mania a potu_.
column3: This idea of sudden immersion had been suggested to me by reading in some medical work the good effect of the shower bath in a case where the patient was suffering from underscore mania a potu underscore.

column2: Finding that I could now trust my companions to hold the end of the rope, I again made three or four plunges into the cabin, although it was now quite dark, and a gentle but long swell from the northward rendered the hulk somewhat unsteady.
column3: Finding that I could now trust my companions to hold the end of the rope, I again made three or four plunges into the cabin, although it was now quite dark, and a gentle but long swell from the northward rendered the hulk somewhat unsteady.

column2: In the course of these attempts I succeeded in bringing up two case-knives, a three-gallon jug, empty, and a blanket, but nothing which could serve us for food.
column3: In the course of these attempts I succeeded in bringing up two case knives, a three gallon jug, empty, and a blanket, but nothing which could serve us for food.

column2: I continued my efforts, after getting these articles, until I was completely exhausted, but brought up nothing else.
column3: I continued my efforts, after getting these articles, until I was completely exhausted, but brought up nothing else.

column2: During the night Parker and Peters occupied themselves by turns in the same manner; but nothing coming to hand, we now gave up this attempt in despair, concluding that we were exhausting ourselves in vain.
column3: During the night Parker and Peters occupied themselves by turns in the same manner; but nothing coming to hand, we now gave up this attempt in despair, concluding that we were exhausting ourselves in vain.

column2: We passed the remainder of this night in a state of the most intense mental and bodily anguish that can possibly be imagined.
column3: We passed the remainder of this night in a state of the most intense mental and bodily anguish that can possibly be imagined.

column2: The morning of the sixteenth at length dawned, and we looked eagerly around the horizon for relief, but to no purpose.
column3: The morning of the sixteenth at length dawned, and we looked eagerly around the horizon for relief, but to no purpose.

column2: The sea was still smooth, with only a long swell from the northward, as on yesterday.
column3: The sea was still smooth, with only a long swell from the northward, as on yesterday.

column2: This was the sixth day since we had tasted either food or drink, with the exception of the bottle of port wine, and it was clear that we could hold out but a very little while longer unless something could be obtained.
column3: This was the sixth day since we had tasted either food or drink, with the exception of the bottle of port wine, and it was clear that we could hold out but a very little while longer unless something could be obtained.

column2: I never saw before, nor wish to see again, human beings so utterly emaciated as Peters and Augustus.
column3: I never saw before, nor wish to see again, human beings so utterly emaciated as Peters and Augustus.

column2: Had I met them on shore in their present condition I should not have had the slightest suspicion that I had ever beheld them.
column3: Had I met them on shore in their present condition I should not have had the slightest suspicion that I had ever beheld them.

column2: Their countenances were totally changed in character, so that I could not bring myself to believe them really the same individuals with whom I had been in company but a few days before.
column3: Their countenances were totally changed in character, so that I could not bring myself to believe them really the same individuals with whom I had been in company but a few days before.

column2: Parker, although sadly reduced, and so feeble that he could not raise his head from his bosom, was not so far gone as the other two.
column3: Parker, although sadly reduced, and so feeble that he could not raise his head from his bosom, was not so far gone as the other two.

column2: He suffered with great patience, making no complaint, and endeavouring to inspire us with hope in every manner he could devise.
column3: He suffered with great patience, making no complaint, and endeavouring to inspire us with hope in every manner he could devise.

column2: For myself, although at the commencement of the voyage I had been in bad health, and was at all times of a delicate constitution, I suffered less than any of us, being much less reduced in frame, and retaining my powers of mind in a surprising degree, while the rest were completely prostrated in intellect, and seemed to be brought to a species of second childhood, generally simpering in their expressions, with idiotic smiles, and uttering the most absurd platitudes.
column3: For myself, although at the commencement of the voyage I had been in bad health, and was at all times of a delicate constitution, I suffered less than any of us, being much less reduced in frame, and retaining my powers of mind in a surprising degree, while the rest were completely prostrated in intellect, and seemed to be brought to a species of second childhood, generally simpering in their expressions, with idiotic smiles, and uttering the most absurd platitudes.

column2: At intervals, however, they would appear to revive suddenly, as if inspired all at once with a consciousness of their condition, when they would spring upon their feet in a momentary flash of vigour, and speak, for a short period, of their prospects, in a manner altogether rational, although full of the most intense despair.
column3: At intervals, however, they would appear to revive suddenly, as if inspired all at once with a consciousness of their condition, when they would spring upon their feet in a momentary flash of vigour, and speak, for a short period, of their prospects, in a manner altogether rational, although full of the most intense despair.

column2: It is possible, however, that my companions may have entertained the same opinion of their own condition as I did of mine, and that I may have unwittingly been guilty of the same extravagances and imbecilities as themselves--this is a matter which cannot be determined.
column3: It is possible, however, that my companions may have entertained the same opinion of their own condition as I did of mine, and that I may have unwittingly been guilty of the same extravagances and imbecilities as themselves-this is a matter which cannot be determined.

column2: About noon Parker declared that he saw land off the larboard quarter, and it was with the utmost difficulty I could restrain him from plunging into the sea with the view of swimming toward it.
column3: About noon Parker declared that he saw land off the larboard quarter, and it was with the utmost difficulty I could restrain him from plunging into the sea with the view of swimming toward it.

column2: Peters and Augustus took little notice of what he said, being apparently wrapped up in moody contemplation.
column3: Peters and Augustus took little notice of what he said, being apparently wrapped up in moody contemplation.

column2: Upon looking in the direction pointed out, I could not perceive the faintest appearance of the shore--indeed, I was too well aware that we were far from any land to indulge in a hope of that nature.
column3: Upon looking in the direction pointed out, I could not perceive the faintest appearance of the shore-indeed, I was too well aware that we were far from any land to indulge in a hope of that nature.

column2: It was a long time, nevertheless, before I could convince Parker of his mistake.
column3: It was a long time, nevertheless, before I could convince Parker of his mistake.

column2: He then burst into a flood of tears, weeping like a child, with loud cries and sobs, for two or three hours, when becoming exhausted, he fell asleep.
column3: He then burst into a flood of tears, weeping like a child, with loud cries and sobs, for two or three hours, when becoming exhausted, he fell asleep.

column2: Peters and Augustus now made several ineffectual efforts to swallow portions of the leather.
column3: Peters and Augustus now made several ineffectual efforts to swallow portions of the leather.

column2: I advised them to chew it and spit it out; but they were too excessively debilitated to be able to follow my advice.
column3: I advised them to chew it and spit it out; but they were too excessively debilitated to be able to follow my advice.

column2: I continued to chew pieces of it at intervals, and found some relief from so doing; my chief distress was for water, and I was only prevented from taking a draught from the sea by remembering the horrible consequences which thus have resulted to others who were similarly situated with ourselves.
column3: I continued to chew pieces of it at intervals, and found some relief from so doing; my chief distress was for water, and I was only prevented from taking a draught from the sea by remembering the horrible consequences which thus have resulted to others who were similarly situated with ourselves.

column2: The day wore on in this manner, when I suddenly discovered a sail to the eastward, and on our larboard bow.
column3: The day wore on in this manner, when I suddenly discovered a sail to the eastward, and on our larboard bow.

column2: She appeared to be a large ship, and was coming nearly athwart us, being probably twelve or fifteen miles distant.
column3: She appeared to be a large ship, and was coming nearly athwart us, being probably twelve or fifteen miles distant.

column2: None of my companions had as yet discovered her, and I forbore to tell them of her for the present, lest we might again be disappointed of relief.
column3: None of my companions had as yet discovered her, and I forbore to tell them of her for the present, lest we might again be disappointed of relief.

column2: At length upon her getting nearer, I saw distinctly that she was heading immediately for us, with her light sails filled.
column3: At length upon her getting nearer, I saw distinctly that she was heading immediately for us, with her light sails filled.

column2: I could now contain myself no longer, and pointed her out to my fellow-sufferers. They immediately sprang to their feet, again indulging in the most extravagant demonstrations of joy, weeping, laughing in an idiotic manner, jumping, stamping upon the deck, tearing their hair, and praying and cursing by turns.
column3: I could now contain myself no longer, and pointed her out to my fellow sufferers. They immediately sprang to their feet, again indulging in the most extravagant demonstrations of joy, weeping, laughing in an idiotic manner, jumping, stamping upon the deck, tearing their hair, and praying and cursing by turns.

column2: I was so affected by their conduct, as well as by what I considered a sure prospect of deliverance, that I could not refrain from joining in with their madness, and gave way to the impulses of my gratitude and ecstasy by lying and rolling on the deck, clapping my hands, shouting, and other similar acts, until I was suddenly called to my recollection, and once more to the extreme human misery and despair, by perceiving the ship all at once with her stern fully presented toward us, and steering in a direction nearly opposite to that in which I had at first perceived her.
column3: I was so affected by their conduct, as well as by what I considered a sure prospect of deliverance, that I could not refrain from joining in with their madness, and gave way to the impulses of my gratitude and ecstasy by lying and rolling on the deck, clapping my hands, shouting, and other similar acts, until I was suddenly called to my recollection, and once more to the extreme human misery and despair, by perceiving the ship all at once with her stern fully presented toward us, and steering in a direction nearly opposite to that in which I had at first perceived her.

column2: It was some time before I could induce my poor companions to believe that this sad reverse in our prospects had actually taken place.
column3: It was some time before I could induce my poor companions to believe that this sad reverse in our prospects had actually taken place.

column2: They replied to all my assertions with a stare and a gesture implying that they were not to be deceived by such misrepresentations.
column3: They replied to all my assertions with a stare and a gesture implying that they were not to be deceived by such misrepresentations.

column2: The conduct of Augustus most sensibly affected me.
column3: The conduct of Augustus most sensibly affected me.

column2: In spite of all I could say or do to the contrary, he persisted in saying that the ship was rapidly nearing us, and in making preparations to go on board of her.
column3: In spite of all I could say or do to the contrary, he persisted in saying that the ship was rapidly nearing us, and in making preparations to go on board of her.

column2: Some seaweed floating by the brig, he maintained that it was the ship's boat, and endeavoured to throw himself upon it, howling and shrieking in the most heartrending manner, when I forcibly restrained him from thus casting himself into the sea.
column3: Some seaweed floating by the brig, he maintained that it was the ship's boat, and endeavoured to throw himself upon it, howling and shrieking in the most heartrending manner, when I forcibly restrained him from thus casting himself into the sea.

column2: Having become in some degree pacified, we continued to watch the ship until we finally lost sight of her, the weather becoming hazy, with a light breeze springing up.
column3: Having become in some degree pacified, we continued to watch the ship until we finally lost sight of her, the weather becoming hazy, with a light breeze springing up.

column2: As soon as she was entirely gone, Parker turned suddenly toward me with an expression of countenance which made me shudder.
column3: As soon as she was entirely gone, Parker turned suddenly toward me with an expression of countenance which made me shudder.

column2: There was about him an air of self-possession which I had not noticed in him until now, and before he opened his lips my heart told me what he would say.
column3: There was about him an air of self possession which I had not noticed in him until now, and before he opened his lips my heart told me what he would say.

column2: He proposed, in a few words, that one of us should die to preserve the existence of the others.
column3: He proposed, in a few words, that one of us should die to preserve the existence of the others.

column2: CHAPTER 12
column3: CHAPTER twelve

column2: I had for some time past, dwelt upon the prospect of our being reduced to this last horrible extremity, and had secretly made up my mind to suffer death in any shape or under any circumstances rather than resort to such a course.
column3: I had for some time past, dwelt upon the prospect of our being reduced to this last horrible extremity, and had secretly made up my mind to suffer death in any shape or under any circumstances rather than resort to such a course.

column2: Nor was this resolution in any degree weakened by the present intensity of hunger under which I laboured.
column3: Nor was this resolution in any degree weakened by the present intensity of hunger under which I laboured.

column2: The proposition had not been heard by either Peters or Augustus.
column3: The proposition had not been heard by either Peters or Augustus.

column2: I therefore took Parker aside; and mentally praying to God for power to dissuade him from the horrible purpose he entertained, I expostulated with him for a long time, and in the most supplicating manner, begging him in the name of every thing which he held sacred, and urging him by every species of argument which the extremity of the case suggested, to abandon the idea, and not to mention it to either of the other two.
column3: I therefore took Parker aside; and mentally praying to God for power to dissuade him from the horrible purpose he entertained, I expostulated with him for a long time, and in the most supplicating manner, begging him in the name of every thing which he held sacred, and urging him by every species of argument which the extremity of the case suggested, to abandon the idea, and not to mention it to either of the other two.
